This is the best example of a simple, arcade-style "shooting gallery" game on Rift I have witnessed so far. On the surface it may seem just like another carnival game... but it goes deeper than that...

There is a wide selection of realistic firearms of different types that handle uniquely and realistically, and plenty of upgrades and interchangeable accessores to experiment with. Any skilled player should be able to complete all challenges 100% without having to use most of these options, but they definitely have a positive performance impact if employed properly, and are simply fun to try out and mix together. 

In terms of core gameplay, there are a couple different locations and a few different game-modes for each one, all revolving around basic range-style plinking, but with a few twists. 

Besides basic animated target practice, Action stages tactically engage the player with enemies from position-to-position in each environment, while negotiating hostage situations requiring careful shot placement (eg. Time Crisis), and there are zombie challenges as well to test your firepower and bravery. Specialized game modes (such as the Sniper ladder) employ even more unique scenarios that will have you steadying your nerves and exercising your decision-making skills until you sweat. Targets sometimes even seem to have an "AI" like ability to engage with the player! 

Sandbox mode is there for people who just want to mess around and test the limits of the game engine, or simply "try it before you buy it" when shopping for guns and accessories. 

There are some instances where the touch controls can feel a little awkward (such as using your off-hand to steady weapons, or look through a scope) - However, any basic action (grabbing, aiming, firing, reloading, pushing, throwing) is tracked well and feels very engaging and refined.

What makes this game real "five star" material are the details and consistency.

review_title: Great fun, but with a few bugs
one_reviews_text:
The game is fun, could probably use more missions, but you have the sandbox to play around with. 

The good:
-The guns looks and functions feel real
-Reloading feels great
-Customization
-Balanced progression
-Throwing knives at Zombies

The Meh:
-The announcer (at least you can turn him off)
-Needs more missions and more guns (It would be cool if you could make your own missions and share them online.)
-The ability to fire an AK (or any rifle) with maxed out mags, full-auto, one handed, and still maintain accuracy.

The Bad:
-Bugs: sometimes when you grab a rifle your offhand does weird stuff.
On a reload from empty (no round in the chamber) the gun will sometimes auto fire (this is ok for handguns and when rifles are on semi-auto, but terrible when you are on full-auto as it dumps your whole mag into the wall, or floor, or whatever is unfortunate to be at the other end. I'm sorry wooden box, that is always next to you in game, I didn't mean it) At least I haven't found anything game breaking, or any CTD's.
-You can only take one gun with you on missions. I understand why, but it would be more immersive if I could have my rifle and my sidearm on missions especially the WWII and Zombies. You have two holsters on your character, but can't use them both anywhere except the sandbox.
-----------------------------------------------------------------


Overall I give this game a 4/5 and appreciate the hard work of developers who continue to support their games. Keep up the good work!

review_title: Tons of fun, but scoring needs revamped
one_reviews_text: The game itself is awesome.  I've played tons of VR games and this ranks with the best.  I LOVE how the guns load exactly like the real thing (changing the magazine with a round in the chamber saves you from releasing the slide... awesome attention to detail.)  If I were to improve anything, it would be to adjust the scoring.  You should get big bonuses for using iron sights, or fewer upgrades.  As it is, there's no motivation to use anything but a completely tricked out weapon (100-round mag, silencer, laser scope, zombie rounds, etc.).  Another thing I like is that the developer clearly listens to feedback on here, which is very cool.  Awesome game.  Worth every penny.

This is the most fun that I have had playing VR.  So much fun that until my notifications popped up saying that there was an update, I didn't even realize that it was an Early Access title. Knowing that it was still in beta when I was playing all those hours and nights have me very excited to move forward with the devs and the game in anticipation of what is next. Every game has downfalls in UI, graphics and physics and this game is no exception. Out of all the shooting VR games on the market this game hits the mark in the fact that you can pick it up and play against fun challenges with the most challenging thing being yourself. Whether I'm trying to beat my best time or getting frustrated that I shot a hostage because I wasn't paying attention and have a hair trigger. This game allows me and my friends to step up and take turns seeing who is the best shot. A suggestion on future updates would be maybe duck hunt-ing (hint hint) or more visual explosions, meaning that a visual fireworks show while shooting would give the eye and ear some awesome visual displays. I don't mean actual fireworks but, there are so many other shooting games where I have to dodge bullets or take cover that honestly gets old after awhile. one_reviews_text:
I actually like this game, and play it late night when I have nothing better to do. I see this as the most accurate VR gun game. The guns in the game are based on real and current weapons with every functionality on them included. Even the safety works. 

    There is a slight learning curve for new players because of the accuracies. You need to pick your gun up and hold it. If you release the side trigger on the holding hand, you'll drop it. You need to load the magazine by picking it from your belt, inserting it in the gun, and then finally charging it.

    You do have an unlimited number of reloads. The game does get progressively more difficult, so watch your bullet count. Reloading before running out means you don't have to charge the weapon which will save you some time.

    The money/points system is pretty good. When you do well in a match, you are awarded cash. You can use that cash to buy new guns and/or modifications. Choose them wisely as some of them really are pointless. 

   As said, it does get repetitive. There are only a handful of different game modes that you complete depending on the type of weapon you have. I hope more dynamic modes come into play. It would be interesting to see some puzzle games incorporated. 

    All-in-all it's a pretty fun and engaging game. You can easily get lost in it, and spend what feels like minutes, but are actual hours passed. There are online tutorials on how to revert it to a new game once you hit a wall due to bad purchase decisions or just too hard to complete. A "Start Over" option in the Settings is very much needed.

review_title: Fantastic Game for any gun enthusiast
one_reviews_text:
I have played Gun Club 3 on the mobile and virtually completed the entirety of it. After updates came far and few in between I stopped playing and eventually forgot about it. Recently getting into VR i noticed Gun Club VR being released, and realised maybe why updates started running short on their mobile genre. When I saw Gun Club VR on sale I decided to give it another whirl even though i already completely knew what to expect.

Gun Club VR has pretty simple gameplay, but the ability to have a high skill ceiling. And to me, its a completely different game from any of its predecessors as such. There is no story or campaign, just a series of target training courses. But its simplicity in execution doesnt mean its easy as the further you progress the targets become tougher and stay up for shorter periods of time, hence the skill ceiling. It is exceptionally good fun for honing reaction speed and mucking around with guns in a fairly non-violent or gory fashion.

However, I only gave it 4 stars as it fails to me on a few things. First of all, the sound is quite honestly archaic. The shooting and reloading sounds are very stock or royalty free, they seem unedited and are exceptionally loud. They are the one thing that makes the experience feel unrealistic and i hope they change them in the future. the next issue is probably more likely to be fixed very soon and that is the over use of the grip button for reloading. Whilst changing a magazine feels satisfying, charging the weapon can be very frustrating as you may grip the gun itself or even grab the magazine that you just loaded in all unintentionally. Perhaps they should use the grip button for magazine switching then the trigger on the non-dominant hand to charge the weapon. Maybe it should be an option as well.

Overall, the game is great fun. I am looking forward to what they are bringing out and fixing the issues above. Im also excited to see how they are going to crack snipers...

I’m a serious shooter. I spend hours at the range every week, and gobs of money on reloading ammo and firearms. Needless to say, the Early Access version of Gun Club VR caught my eye, and the attention of the people I shoot with regularly.  For us, this game is an easy 10-stars. It is incredibly fun, realistic enough to be a cut above a “game” and has such incredible potential.
Over the course of the months I have completed every single scenario, working to get 4 stars and all cash on each, with each weapon class. It took a lot of practice and long hours of total sweat filled bliss, but I made it through all the game with the top scores. It’s absolutely excellent for “gun nuts” as a fun way to blow off steam without having to spend a c-note on ammo.  We are all buying Rifts just to play this game. For the price of a new pistol, this game makes the Rift worth the purchase price for people that love to shoot.
Thinks I like:
I like the handling of the weapons on the rift controllers.  You get the groove of running the motions, charging the weapons, reloading, point of aim, etc.  Dumping magazines, changing the fire control to safe/semi/full is great. Right there on the thumb controller. Some of the weapon systems are a little complex, like the P90 and Street Sweeper, but you can get the hang of them quickly.  Overall, high marks here, and it can only get better.
I love the scenarios. The standard Hogan’s alley is very well done. Targets pop in and out in random orders, stay up the right amount of time, and are placed well.  I like the mechanics for the mix of armored and unarmored targets, as well as the armed targets with laser pointers. It adds a perfect level of tension, excitement, and urgency to each scenario.

one_reviews_text:
Essentially, this is a shooting gallery with a variety of real-world firearms from four categories: pistols, SMGs, shotguns, and rifles. You fire at targets in a variety of different courses and modes, from a basic tactical simulation (don't shoot the hostages!) to zombies. Well, flat wooden zombies (who still want your brains). /

Don't let the "wooden target" thing disuade you, though! The targets pop up as quickly as you can shoot them, and some shoot (or bite) back. In addition, there are time limits in place, as well as a scoring system for each level. As you progress, you'll earn money which will let you buy more weapons and upgrades for said weapons. /

The attention to detail is quite good in most cases! Unlike many other games, Gun Club uses the capacitive sensors on the Touch controller to allow your in-game avatar to exercise proper trigger discipline. That makes the fact that the trigger on the gun model is static rather off-putting, though. /

That said, the grind--as stated in other reviews--feels a bit drawn out. I constantly get the feeling that I'm going to have all of the levels beaten before I even come close to even unlocking all of the accessories for a single weapon, let alone collecting all of the guns. /

Another issue that I keep running into is the position of the menu button. Rather than the dedicated menu button on the Touch controller being used, the B/Y buttons open the menu. This can be a problem when reloading weapons that hold the magazine in the grip, such as the pistols or the TMP. When I follow the magazine up the Y button ends up bumping against the bottom of my right controller, pausing the game. /

Finally, in the zombies game, larger weapons can go through the targets, preventing you from hitting them. I had to stick with my TMP on the later levels to keep that from happening. /

The goods definitely outweigh the bads, though. This game is amazingly fun and I look forward to it getting even better as it nears its full release!

My second gripe is the lack of an attachment UI. It's rather tiring to have to go to a shop and browse to the exact mod just to attach it to your weapon, rather than be able to browse through available mods on the main weapon screen.
review_feedback: Thanks for the great feedback, two handed weapon handling is something we are focusing on right now. We agree that it can be awkward. We will keep you posted on the progress. We are also planning on a more intuitive Attachment solution so stay tuned for that also.

review_title: This game is AWESOME! A shooter's dream!

The multiple game modes is a joy as well. I think the addition of zombie mode was genius. I won't spoil it but by the end levels of zombie shooting it gets crazy scary. My friends and I were laughing hysterically at some of the crazy luck shots we were pulling off and doing our best to progress through some of the hard missions. In closing, this game is EASILY worth the 19.99 they're charging. You'll love it!
